question.text: In an <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi></math>-ray tube, electrons emitted from a filament (cathode) carrying current <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>I</mi></math> hit a target (anode) at a distance <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>d</mi></math> from the cathode. The target is kept at a potential <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>V</mi></math> higher than the cathode resulting in emission of continuous and characteristic X-rays. If the filament current <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>I</mi></math> is decreased to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>,</mo></math> the potential difference <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>V</mi></math> is increased to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mi>V</mi><mo>,</mo></math> and the separation distance <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>d</mi></math> is reduced to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>,</mo></math> then

options.text: the cut-off wavelength will reduce to half, and the wavelengths of the characteristic X-rays will remain the same
the cut-off wavelength as well as the wavelengths of the characteristic X-rays will remain the same
the cut-off wavelength will reduce to half, and the intensities of all the X-rays will decrease
the cut-off wavelength will become two times larger, and the intensity of all the X-rays will decrease

solution.text:
Cut off wavelength λC∝1V

So, cut-off wavelength becomes half.

Characteristic x-ray depends on target atomic number, so it remains same.

On decreasing filament current number of electron decrease, so intensity of X -ray decreases.
